In the past, we have tried several log drivers and have run into promptness issues.  When output has to pass through docker itself and the volume of data is large, the output can be delayed significantly causing the invoker to be stalled.  There is no guarantee after an action is finished that Docker has necessarily made the output available and the more complex the log driver, the greater the expected and actual delay.  In a multi-tenant system that will be under a heavy and churning load, this problem can become severe and we ended up looking directly at the file system (/var/docker) to get the logs in the fastest possible manner so that writeback and end-to-end latency can be minimized. 

Other issues with log-driver include memory leaks and interference with docker's global lock.   There is a general pattern where the more logic has to run in docker, the slower basic docker operations can become.  When we were using other log drivers and the system was under heavy load by churning containers as fast as possible, docker ps could take several seconds to respond making administrative tasks on the invoker unacceptably slow.  It's possible that fluentd+docker1.12 no longer has these issues but it would be a very significant change that would require a lot of correctness (under load) and performance testing to prove no performance degradation.

alternative proposal:

high-level sketch here, low-level details to be discussed.

We create a built-in system feed in the whisk.system package, called 'exception'.   Define the set of abnormal exit conditions to be, for example, E := { 'error', 'abort' }.     You can instantiate the exception feed for action A and exit condition C, which causes the system feed to fire a trigger when A exits with condition C.

So to install an exception handler the user creates a rule to handle the exception feed.

Note that this solution is a fire-and-forget asynchronous approach to exception handling.     It does not allow action composition with exception handlers in composed actions, so is weaker than lexically scoped exception handling in a language.    However, this proposal seems like a less ambitious, less disruptive change to the programming model. as compared to a new construct for scoped exception handling with composition.

@bjustin-ibm i agree we shouldn't provide code samples for any random npm package we provide ootb. However, providing direct doc guidance to users on how to programmatically interact with one of our key event providers only has upsides in terms of user experience, in my mind.

I think we also need to look at the ease of use / dev experience here:

if B does some auth work and should be able to return a 401 or a 403 (or sth else), it would be most straightforward to me as a dev if i could just return a 403/401 or whatever from B -- so I like @markusthoemmes . When I'm writing B I *know* that this can result in a 401/403, so why not let devs just code it in there?

Having to add that information to be metadata of the action makes my life as a dev more cumbersome, I have to code the action * change the metadata.

You're focusing on the narrow case - the more general programming model question is to allow for try/catch (or in scala terms recover with). In Steve's latter proposal, he also describes what could be the start of allowing developers to create handlers for system generated events. As in: actions completed with errror, trigger an event. The developer can choose to register a handler via a rule for such an event or not. In the context of this issue, the event would be produced on action error. It's not far fetched to generalize even further (and that's related to https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/1652).

i agree there is a broader question to be addressed re try/catch.

For the specific question of 'how do i return custom http codes if my action fails', i think there is an opp for delivering a better / more fit-for-purpose UX than just offering a general mechanism for try/catch. maybe we should separate this into 2 issues vs lumping it all into one?

Now to the specific use case where in effect some action that fails within the sequence needs to actually set the HTTP header for the response, BUT also at the same time terminate the rest of the sequence, there are two concerns in fact: 1. If the action behaves like a web handler and responds with a json object that terminates the http connection, it will not short circuit the rest of the sequence since it produced an activation result. 2. If it returns an error to short circuit the sequence then it can't respond with the http headers etc to terminate the http request. 

Going further while you might suggest well on error the response should match the requirements for terminating the http request (ie instead of {headers,code} it becomes {error:{headers,code}}) then the issue is that an action inside the sequence that is not really aware of the http context could not possibly do that. So what do you do?

@mbehrendt we do have the ability to allow actions to respond as http headers. The issue here is not that specifically. It's what happens under composition when you compose actions where some of which are just "functions".

> Going further while you might suggest well on error the response should match the requirements for terminating the http request (ie instead of {headers,code} it becomes {error:{headers,code}}) then the issue is that an action inside the sequence that is not really aware of the http context could not possibly do that.

in which sense is it not available to the action? eg the action could return a http json with 403 as the code, which would be interpreted by the controller?

Say you have a sequence A => B => C. Say C is a web action and can set the status etc on the http request. Now let B be an action from a public package e.g. Watson translate. If B fails it returns {error:}. As a result C does not run. If C ran then it can respond with a proper status code. But how do you get C to run when B fails? You don't have access to B's code it's in a package you don't own. Options are: That's what we started :)

well, you just changed the scenario to require the more general try/catch mechanism :-) . It's a valid one, but not the one I described and which I understood from Nick. We'll have many cases where no 3rd party action is being used, and making them as simple as possible has benefits.

> you just changed the scenario to require the more general try/catch mechanism

I did? That's the scenarios described by Nick in the issue description. I just made it clearer: he points out that `B` needs to short circuit the sequence (don't run C) but needs to terminate the HTTP response as well. So how do you do both things?

That I used B to mean third party action you can't modify is to exactly separate the two distinct issues.

> I did? 

yeah, I think you did by making B a 3rd party action. In a world where code of all actions is under my control, things become much easier -- so why impose the increased complexity of a world with both custom & 3rd party code on folks who are just writing actions by themselves?

OK - so if the developer controls all the code, how does B short circuit C from running (the semantics of a sequence is once an action returns an error, it terminates the sequence)? If it does by returning `{error: {code: 403}}` to stop C from running AND terminate the HTTP with the desired code, are you then suggesting that every action in the sequence now has to return with an appropriate error response that knows how to terminate the HTTP connection as well? Even if a developer is reusing their own code and controls all of it, there is no free lunch: either every action in the sequence (think more than 3) must be aware that it needs to respond with an object that can terminate the HTTP request, or every action must be wrapped with another action that does the same, or some thing else. Back to where this issue started, no? Making B a black box just forces one to accept this quicker.

> either every action in the sequence (think more than 3) must be aware that it needs to respond with an object that can terminate the HTTP request

right -- is there an issue with that? As a dev writing a set of actions, which are put into a sequence, I know that i'm writing this to be used in an http context or not. If i'm writing this in an http context, it would be natural to me to return http codes.

I agree there are more general purpose use cases that have to be served in a more general purpose fashion, but i think it's good objective to make the simple things simple.

I am concerned that it makes reusing previously developed assets harder: you can't reuse them as is. It conflates the behavior of the action with its context. It is bad for software engineering practices. Is it akin to dictating every method (action) one writes must try catch/recover vs selectively adding try catch/recover where it makes sense for the context of the composition.

The simple thing is not so simple for these reasons: it's intrusive. I'm also not stating that the proposal for recover is simple. Or the system generated events proposal is simple. I am pointing out that there are tradeoffs to each whether its on the programming model, the developer's burden, or the system's implementation.

re: the asynchronous recovery proposal by @sjfink 

how would the 403s filter back to the client, which is expecting a response to its request? in my particular example, the client needs to redirect the user to a login page, because the user's token has expired. how can the client distinguish "irrevocably failed invocation" from "maybe possibly at some point in the future, 403"?

to clarify -- i'm not suggesting an either/or. I *think* we'll need 2 approaches, one for the simple/fit-for-purpose case and one for the generic case. There is no good or bad in this, since it seems like we have 2 different, but both valid use cases. As you stated there are trade-offs.

By making 2 options available to the developer, we give him choice to pick the one that fits best his needs. If we only offered the simple or generic one, we'd either not solve the generic problem or make the simple case harder than it is, which is not desirable.

I'm not hung up on the implementation approach (ideally we can come up with a unified one) and very interested in alternative options, but only offering folks a more-complex-than-needed approach for asset reuse (even if they don't want to) is I think as bad as not allowing them to reuse assets.
adding to what I wrote above: I shouldn't have called it simple vs complex but rather sth like "code is fully under my control" vs. "I want to reuse unmodified assets"

the tricky part of my particular example is that action `B`'s 403 failure mode has meaning that can't be lost in a more generic "oops, some action in my sequence messed up" error handler. thus, however we do this, some specific information from `B`, on token expiration, must "percolate out".

i.e.
```
A.then(B).then(C).catch(handle403)
```

doesn't quite work, because the sequence may have many failure modes, in addition to token expiration at point `B`.

how does `B` communicate this information outwards? in a richer language, typed exceptions would help. `B` would throw a `TokenExpirationException`, and the sequence-level handler would match on it, and communicate with the client.

in their absence, do we just "pay the piper", and force every action to be a participant in a particular client protocol (http, in my example)? or is there some way to separate the concerns, so that `B` knows only about token expiration, and the sequence (being web-exported) handles the protocol issues...

whatever we do, some change will be needed to the core. because, right now, it tosses a 400 back to the client, no matter what happens. i've worked around this, for now, by interpreting the body of 400 responses.

in that sense, i've achieved a partial victory, in that `B` knows nothing about http! however, we've lost the ability to clear server-side (a.k.a. "Secure") cookies, and do proper redirects.

i think async/recoverWith is an important enough pattern that we should find some way to navigate in that direction.

we either need synchronous recovery (in my 403 example, where i'd like to consolidate the concern of 403 recovery, and not have it infect every action), or async recovery (e.g. when i want to unify my logging/notification handling, and not have it infect every single action). but, in either case, the need to consolidate handling logic, and separate failure modes from client protocol, and from the choice between sync and async recovery modes... these seem like good goals

Reading the comments above, I've been thinking about how as a developer I might want to handle errors in a sequenced-define service and also extend web actions with features like authentication without having to replicate lots of boilerplate. 

If I want to expose a translation service, using the built-in watson package, I can imagine building the following sequence:

S1: A -> B -> C
A: parse HTTP event parameters and return data to translate into the expected output format.
B: built-in watson translate service
C: format translation output into expected JSON format. 

Now, what if B fails? I like the Promise based example of being able to attach a `catch()` equivalent to a sequence that handles the rejection and would be able to return the expected HTTP response for failure cases like this. 
S1: A -> B -> C
     errors   -> D

D would return` {statusCode: 403, message: "some error message"}`.

At a later point, I might want to add authentication to this service. Rather than having to manually update A to handle this (which would be replicated in every sequence), I would create a new action (E) that handles this. If authentication passes, it just returns input parameters, other it throws the rejection. 

This would allow me to define a new sequence, S2, adding auth onto my service with minimal effort. I could use this pattern for adding auth to any service. 

S2: E -> S1 

This second sequence would not have a`catch()` path defined. If E fails, it throws the error with the failure response in. If S1 fails, the result returned by D will be returned as the error response.
